newsitem.title: FRANCE: French wheat exports to Egypt hinge on price.
newsitem.headline: French wheat exports to Egypt hinge on price.

text.p: France could sell between 200,000 and 300,000 tonnes of wheat to Egypt provided it competes with other origins, notably Australia and the United States, European exporters said on Wednesday.
Egypt is in the market for 50,000 tonnes of Argentine, U.S., or French wheat for loading in March or April.
But European exporters estimate it may end up buying between 300,000 and 400,000 tonnes, while U.S. exporters say Egypt could purchase 800,000 tonnes.
The European Union, Australia, the United States and Argentina are all expected to line up for the business.
"Egypt will hinge on prices. I do not see how the European Union could sell without being aggressive," one trader said.
Exporters estimate French wheat stands a chance against its main rivals if it is priced at $145-146 per tonne fob for April delivery.
But this would require a significant increase in EU wheat export subsidies.
French wheat has a paper value of $146-147 per tonne but last week's EU export licence award valued wheat at around $150 per tonne.
"We do not stand a chance with Egypt at $150," one French exporter said.
Guy Legras, director general of agriculture at the EU Commission, on Tuesday ruled out a more aggressive stance.
He said that the European Union would not confront Australia on the world market, being satisfied with its recent exports.

Australia, which has a record crop this year, has just sold 110,000 tonnes of hard wheat to Egypt for February-March delivery at around $190 a tonne, including cost and freight. It has already sent word it will chase further contracts.
"Competition with Australian wheat becomes difficult even with wheat priced at $190," one European trader said.

But exporters warned that it was tricky to compare the prices of French and Australian wheat because Australian had a quality advantage. They said French wheat could benefit from Egypt's desire to diversify supply sources as some exporters will face logistical problems.
In recent months France has sold wheat to Egypt as supplies of U.S old-crop dwindled.
Exporters said logistical hurdles are already plaguing Argentina and some may be in store for Australia in March and April.
But exporters need to land Egyptian business now because new North American supplies will hit the market in May-June.
World buyers are expected to slow imports in May ahead of the arrival of the new U.S. crop, which could be offered at a $10 a tonne discount over the old crop.
